Package com.accele.gage

Class GAGE

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.accele.gage.GAGE
  • public class GAGE
extends java.lang.Object
    The primary class for interfacing with the engine. All operations relating to GAGE must ultimately be done through this class. Only one instance of this class may be present in any given instance of the JVM, and it must be created on the main thread. GAGE may spawn additional threads at any given point during its runtime to offload different processes.

    Before interacting with any part of GAGE, it must first be initialized using the init(int, int, String) method. Once initialized, the GAGE instance can be accessed using getInstance(). After initializing the engine and any additional resources, the engine can be started using the start() method. For example: 

     GAGE.init(640, 480, "My Game");
 GAGE.getInstance().getStateRegistry().register(new ExampleState());
 GAGE.getInstance().setCurrentState("example_state");
 GAGE.getInstance().start();

    Because GAGE is a state-based engine, it requires an implementation of the GameState class. This implementation must be registered in the state registry using getStateRegistry() and then set using setCurrentState(String). Without calling these two methods first, calling start() will throw an error.

    To stop the engine at any point after calling start(), either stop() or forceQuit() may be used, although stop() is preferable. Do not call System.exit(n) or Runtime.getRuntime().halt(n) as there are necessary shutdown hooks GAGE must run before terminating. These hooks are not registered in the JVM's shutdown hook registry, so they must run on their own before terminating the program.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    Version:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    William Garland

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the engine. This method will perform any necessary checks (such as checking for a loaded GameState) before actually running the primary game loop. Once this method is called, normal execution will not return to the caller until stop() is called.

        Because GAGE is a state-based engine, it requires an implementation of the GameState class. This implementation must be registered in the state registry using getStateRegistry() and then set using setCurrentState(String). Without calling these two methods first, calling start() will throw an error.

        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if no instance of GameState is loaded in the current context

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the engine. This method will allow the engine to terminate normally and is the preferred method to stop the engine. Calling this method will cause all system resources held by the engine to be released, so starting another instance of the engine in the same JVM instance must be done in the exact same way as it was initially created.

        Note that although this method will stop the engine, it will not terminate immediately; the engine will begin its shutdown process at the end of the current game loop cycle. Once all necessary shutdown hooks have run, execution will return to the caller of the start() method. To stop the engine immediately, use forceQuit().

      • forceQuit

        public void forceQuit()
        Forces the engine to stop. This method will immediately terminate the engine and the running JVM instance and attempt to release any held system resources.

        This method should only be used as a last resort; Whatever frame the engine was currently on will not be allowed to finish execution. To stop the engine under normal conditions, use stop().

      • getWindow

        public Window getWindow()
        Returns the instance of Window used by GAGE.
        Returns:
        the window used by the running instance of the engine

      • getGameTime

        public double getGameTime()
        Returns the time in seconds since the engine was started.

        The resolution of the timer implementation is system-dependent, but is usually accurate to the microsecond or the nanosecond.

        Returns:
        the time, in seconds, since the engine was started

      • getRand

        public java.util.Random getRand()
        Returns the instance of Random used by GAGE.

        GAGE uses the default implementation of Random, which employs use of the current system time to generate a unique seed.

        Returns:
        the instance of Random used by the running instance of the engine

      • getGraphics

        public Graphics getGraphics()
        Returns the instance of Graphics used by GAGE.

        This method is intended to yield the Graphics instance for retrieving and modifying graphical settings only; at no point should the draw functions be called outside of the render(Graphics, double) method.

        Returns:
        the Graphics used by the running instance of the engine

      • deferEvent

        public void deferEvent​(java.util.function.Consumer<GAGE> event)
        Adds the specified event to the event queue. All events in the event queue will run in an arbitrary order at the end of the next frame.
        Parameters:
        event - the event to add to the event queue

      • getCurrentState

        public GameState getCurrentState()
        Returns the current state used by GAGE. If no state is set, this method will throw an IllegalStateException.
        Returns:
        the instance of GameState used by the running instance of the engine
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if no instance of GameState is loaded in the current context

      • setCurrentState

        public void setCurrentState​(java.lang.String registryId,
                            boolean exitOld,
                            boolean initNew)
        Sets the state to be used by the engine. If the specified state is not registered in the state registry, this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
        Parameters:
        registryId - the registry id of the GameState to use
        exitOld - whether the exit() method of the currently set GameState should be called. If no state is currently loaded, setting this to true will have no effect.
        initNew - whether the init() method of the new GameState should be called
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified GameState is not registered in the state registry

      • setCurrentState

        public void setCurrentState​(java.lang.String registryId)
        Sets the state to be used by the engine. If the specified state is not registered in the state registry, this method will throw an IllegalArgumentException. This method will call the exit() method of the currently set GameState (if applicable) and the init() method of the new GameState.
        Parameters:
        registryId - the registry id of the GameState to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified GameState is not registered in the state registry

      • init

        public static void init​(int screenWidth,
                        int screenHeight,
                        java.lang.String title)
        Initializes the engine using the specified screen width, screen height, and title. This method must be called before using any other method in the engine and may only be called once per instance of the engine.
        Parameters:
        screenWidth - the width of the viewable screen area in pixels
        screenHeight - the height of the viewable screen area in pixels
        title - the title of the window
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if GAGE was already initialized or if the engine failed any necessary startup checks

      • getInstance

        public static GAGE getInstance()
        Returns the instance of GAGE used to interface with the engine. All actions relating to the engine must be done through the instance returned by this method.
        Returns:
        the instance of GAGE used to interface with the engine

      • isInitialized

        public static boolean isInitialized()
        Returns whether GAGE has already been initialized.
        Returns:
        whether GAGE has already been initialized

      • setCustomWindowHints

        public static void setCustomWindowHints​(int[] hints)
        Sets custom window hints to use when initializing the Window.

        GAGE uses the programmable pipeline version of the LWJGL API, and as a result also uses the GLFW API as the windowing system, so all available window hints can be found in the GLFW class. By default, GAGE uses a predefined set of window hints upon initializing the Window (see the Window class for details). Calling this method will override these presets and instead use the specified custom hints. This method must be called prior to calling the init(int, int, String) method; calling it after GAGE has already been initialized will have no effect.

        Note that this method expects hints to be provided in key-value order; the key for a given window hint is immediately followed by its matching value, which then is followed by subsequent key-value pairs.

        Example:

         setCustomWindowHints(new int[] { GLFW_SAMPLES, 4, GLFW_CONTEXT_VERSION_MAJOR, 3, GLFW_CONTEXT_VERSION_MINOR, 2 });
        Parameters:
        hints - the array of window hints to use when initializing the Window in key-value order
        See Also:
        Window, GLFW

      • useDefaultWindowHints

        public static void useDefaultWindowHints()
        Tells the engine to use the default window hints when initializing the Window.

        GAGE uses a predefined set of window hints by default, so calling this method without also having called setCustomWindowHints(int[]) will have no effect. Additionally, this method must be called prior to calling the init(int, int, String) method; calling it after GAGE has already been initialized will have no effect.

        For the list of default window hints used by GAGE, see the Window class.

        See Also:
        Window
